title: FX's 'Fargo' matches wonderful weirdness of Coen Brothers' film - The Orange County Register
text:
“Fargo,” FX’s rethinking of the Coen Brothers’ great 1996 movie, begins its second season Monday, which gives us a perfect window to binge-watch the wonderfully odd first season.
The film and the series share tone, subject matter and a location in frigid northern Minnesota, but they have distinct stories and characters.
Joel and Ethan Coen, the writers and directors of the film, are executive producers on the series, but neither had a direct hand in its creation. Instead, writer Noah Hawley and a handful of directors did a remarkable job recreating the original’s weird mix of quiet drama and deadpan comedy.
Martin Freeman plays Lester Nygaard, a nebbish bullied by both his wife and a longtime “friend.” Lester’s life is changed by a chance encounter with the itinerant hitman Lorne Malvo (Billy Bob Thornton), an eccentric sociopath who takes Lester under his wing. Malvo helps Lester deal with his problems – in an extremely direct and effective manner.
The challenge of unraveling what Lester and Malvo have done falls to two police officers from different towns: a capable young woman played by Allison Tolman and a skittish single dad played by Colin Hanks. Together, they find the courage to face a malevolence neither could handle alone.
That story winds through myriad complications and introduces a dozen or so memorable side characters through 10 episodes. Among the notable performances are Kate Walsh as a not-very-grieving widow and Keegan-Michael Key and Jordan Peele as a pair of incompetent FBI agents.
As in the movie, Fargo looms as a metaphor for the evil that lurks just across the border of our quiet, well-tended lives.
“FARGO” 
Original run: April-June 2014 on FX
Starred: Martin Freeman, Billy Bob Thornton, Allison Tolman, Colin Hanks
Binge commitment: 10 one-hour episodes
Rating: TV-MA
Watch it: Hulu, Netflix, Amazon Instant Video, others
AD OUT 
How much is it worth to eliminate ads from your streaming experience? Hulu thinks it is $4 a month.
The streaming service recently began offering subscribers a no-commercials plan for $11.99 a month, vs. $7.99 for its standard subscription, which inserts about one minute of commercials per half hour. Both plans offer full access to the Hulu library.
Hulu’s free service has more commercials and a restricted catalog.
